{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3534073,"name":"Brad","username":"MrCauthers","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrcauthers/{size}/250448_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T14:19:59.890Z","cooked":"

Not being an expert with Github, I’m having difficulty coming up with the right steps for this, so please bear with me.

I have a current repo that we are working on as a base code. I would like to be able build multiple projects off of it.

I would like to be able to create clones of the original that can be altered without making changes to the original branch.

HOWEVER, I would also like to be able to make changes to the original branch and be able to pull these into any of the clones without fear of accidentally altering the original branch from the clone.

So, simply:

  1. Make original branch
  2. Create clones
  3. Make changes to original branch that can be pushed to all clones
  4. Make changes to clones that can NOT be accidentally pushed to original
  5. Be able to make changes to original in VSCode and push/pull to/from original Github repo
  6. Be able to pull changes made to original branch to clones in VSCode.
  7. Be able to make changes to clones in VSCode and push/pull to/from clones Github repo

I feel like this should be a common request, but I don’t seem to see a solution anywhere.

I think what you may be looking for is branch protections on GitHub? Essentially you can mark certain branches as protected so it’s necessary to open a pull request to make a change and direct pushes will be rejected.

GitHub Docs

About protected branches - GitHub Docs

You can protect important branches by setting branch protection rules, which define whether collaborators can delete or force push to the branch and set requirements for any pushes to the branch, such as passing status checks or a linear commit...

As I understand, you want to use a repository across multiple projects and avoid accidentally pushing code to the main repository. For this, you can fork a repository and create a pull request when you want to merge your changes. You can also pull updates from the main repository. While doing this, I recommend using the VS Code Source Control tab and extensions or a third-party CLI tool. This is because if there is a conflict, you may need to compare the changes with the main repository and decide which changes to keep. (Since you mentioned cloning, I assumed you would use it in different projects. If it’s the same project, working with branches would be more logical.)

https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/working-with-forks/fork-a-repo

Use branches, add branch protection to prevent pushing to the main branch. Permit only mentors or your leads to do that.

For work in progress, make branches titled appropriately (ie comp/week1, dev/myname, or go by task subsystem/drive). This depends on how many programmers you have, and workflows setup to manage it.

People will git clone the repo, then checkout a branch they want to work on. When they checkout the branch and push, they’ll need write permissions (use GitHub Organizations). From GitHub you can make pull requests adding reviewers/codeowners.

When changes are made on main and need to be merge in, (if using GitHub desktop) you can merge main into your branch, but it creates a mess in the history.

The better option is to fast-forward your branch. VSCode has a button for this on the Git panel. Git Fast-forward merge will ‘re-play’/move your commits in your branch after from the branch is rebased to match main, this makes a linear history of changes. (git merge types)

Generally if you are going for maintainability, using git forks isn’t sustainable since the code can vary a lot. If you have a lot of code reuse, look into submodules or making it a package to be published (IE a jar file in a package registry).
